content.description: Using the arete, climb the southeast slab with decent feet and nothing for hands.  Very stiff V0.
content.protection: Crashpad to cover the small rock.

content.description: Begin on obvious crimps then pull to a bad right hand crimp then to jugs up and left.  Benningfield lists this problem as V2, but consensus seems to be closer to V4. It is worthwhile regardless of the rating.
content.location: It is just right of the downclimb on the south face of the Gill Boulder.

climbs.name: SDS to Northeast Reach (submitted as The Blunt Arete)

content.description:
SDS on positive edges, and make several hard moves up to the positive horizontal crack, utilizing toes hooks and sidepulls. Two more large moves and a small, right hand crimp will get you to the top.

Eds. What is described here is the sit down start to what is known as Bob Horan's "Northeast Reach", and the "Blunt Arete" is a sandbagged version of the Horan Face, as described in the Benningfield/Samet guidebook.
Good holds lead up the northeast corner.

This ascends the line of jugs right of the

North Dihedral

.  The crux is probably the reach to the jug at mid-height from polished feet.  From a nice stance halfway up, you have to make insecure but easy moves to the lip. If you are tall, this problem should feel about V0.
content.location:
It is on the back (North side) just right of

North Dihedral

.

content.description: Start on jugs on the middle of the face.  Get your foot up high and make a huge mantle/reach move to the small somewhat slopping holds near the top. Carefully snag the lip, and top out.
content.location:
This is in the middle of the north face of the Gill Boulder between the

dihedral problem

and the northeast arete.

content.description:
A scary dyno hides right next to the

North Face Dihedral

, it is sort of an eliminate. Start as for the dihedral, but eliminate the right hand crack hold, utilize small crimps on the face, and leap up and left to the top.  This is tall!
Climb the scoop-like dihedral in the middle of the north face.  Make a semi-committing move off the shelf at about half height and topout on good holds.
content.protection: This is a bit high, so crashpads and a spotter are a good idea.

content.description: Start on a small boulder and grab crimpy but good holds. Angle up and right.
content.protection: A couple pads to fix up the ankle breaking landing.
content.location:
This is on the West face of the Gill Boulder on the North end, just left of

606

.

content.description: Go straight up on small edges. To my knowledge, it has only seen 2 ascents, Seth's and mine.
content.location:
This is to the right of

606

.

content.description:
Climb the arete on the southwest side of the boulder topping out at its highest point.

A SDS can be added to this problem making it about V3.
content.protection: Falling is not recommended on this problem.  There are several ankle twisting objects in the landing zone.

content.description: Start on some decent crimps and find your way up the blank face using small features and little feet.
content.location: On the east face of the gill boulder, the starting crimps are in the middle of the face.

content.description: Start at the standard face, go up two moves, go right two moves at a crimp, and go up to finish at a jug.  The start is more difficult now due to the starting blocks having been moved.

606 climbs the center line on the slightly overhanging West face of the Gill Boulder, using small crimps, and technical movement.  Be prepared to grab small holds, and stand on smaller feet.

Start on an obvious, right-facing edge about 3 feet off the ground and move left up the middle of the wall.  The difficulties end when you grab the large, vertical, right-facing sidepull with your right hand and top out using bigger holds.

This problem feels a lot easier when it's cold.
content.location: This boulder problem is located on the West face, about 10 feet to the left of the Southwest arete.  To descend, walk to the South side of the boulder.
